description.narrative:
Accountability Lab Nigeria has proposed under this grant to engage with Nigerians particularly the rights holders of Voice, on their role as citizens in the Open Government Partnership. The project will focus particularly on the current Nigerian Action Plan.
Civic Action Teams (CivActs) are a pioneering citizen feedback, dialogue and community voice platform to ensure accountability in the development process. CivActs collect critical information from communities to solve daily problems for marginalized citizens, close the loop on challenges, and create tools that strengthen communities# ability to self-advocate.
This approach was developed by the Accountability Lab in Nepal after the earthquakes of 2015 to improve the disaster response, it will beadapted to the Nigerian contextto focus on issues of marginalization and exclusion. The process involves training community members (Community Frontline Associates, or CFAs) to collect data on community needs and their perceptions of critical challenges,and feed that data up to decision-makersand back to the community in formats that are both understandable and useful. Through multi-stakeholder town hall meetings, CFAs bring powerholders and community members together to discuss the challenges and perceptions surfaced through the data collection, creating a space where trust can be built and solutions can be co-created.
Under this project, the CivicActs will support women, youth,and persons with disabilities in the Niger Delta region. The CFAs willgenerate data around fiscal governance issues that will be useful to these groups for improving grassroots advocacy using community radio conversations, multi-stakeholder debates and dialogues,and dissemination of infographics. With this, these excludedgroups will be more informed and grassroots activists better equipped to advocate for improved policies, with proposed policy changes as an output.
The current project will use an array of digital toolsand platforms to improve engagement with excluded citizens, and facilitate cross-communication between citizens and government institutions. Responses from citizens will be aggregated in reports and sent to government institutions to request that the latter act in the best interests of excluded groups.
Thus, the sole goal of this project is to equip communities, and marginalized groups in particular, who are affected by a lack of accountability in the extractives sector with useful citizen-generated data for self-advocacy, and disseminate accurate information to engage a broad audience, and create multi-stakeholder spaces that foster trust-building and solutions-driven dialogue.
To achieve this, the project proposes the following objectives:
- to empower marginalized groups through multi-stakeholder dialogues and townhall engagements with public officials in 3 OGP states (Imo, Delta, and Edo) and generate constant feedback to government officials and concerned companies to meet obligations to the communities
- Increase meaningful participationand strengthen the voice of young people, women and other persons with disabilities in governance processes by providing simplified and inclusive information around open governance (such as fiscal transparency e.g. NEITI 2017 Audit Report, etc.) through street vibes, music, infographics and monthly tweet chats.
The activities that will help achieve these objectives are:
Activity I: Sensitizing communities and generating dialogue on transparency in communities affected by extraction, and enablingcitizens to participate in decision-making processes.
Activity II: Outreach and Engagement We will also support NEITI report to translate the report content in creative ways using film, music and infographics to help young people and marginalized groups better understand the report content.

participating-org.narrative:
OAccountability Lab Nigeria is a network of social movement whose vision is a world in which people with power are accountable; a world in which resources are used wisely, decisions benefit everyone fairly, and people lead secure lives. They are keen on catalyzing a new generation of active citizens and responsible leaders around the world by supporting change-makers to develop and implement positive ideas for integrity in their communities. By enabling people to generate the knowledge, skills and networks needed for accountability, they want to unleash positive social and economic change.
They have three mutually-reinforcing objectives: to support apositive movement to build accountability; provide substantive, flexible and long-term support for those leaders who can collectively lead this movement within specific contexts; and support collaboration around accountability and open governance.
AccountabilityLab Nigeria is part of Accountability Lab, a global organization with network labs in Nepal, Pakistan, Liberia, Mali, South Africa and Mexico in addition to Nigeria. They are also affiliated with Open Government Hub DC around accountability and open governance bydeveloping thematic co-working spaces (including Open Government Hubs in Nepal, Mali and Pakistan; and an affiliate hub, called iCampus, in Liberia). They work closely with a number of other international networks and efforts including OGP, the T/A Network and the UN Global Compact and initiatives around SDG16
Their proudest achievement at is being able to build a network of change-makers who are committed to making governance work through their Integrity Icon, Accountability Incubator, SDG 16 Innovation challenge and Voice2Rep project using creative means. Also, being able to builda team of young people who understand the need for good and open governance in Nigeria
The board comprises of 6 members, 3 females and 3 males. who meet every quarter - four (4) times a year. 1. Dr. Yemi Kale (Chairman) - Sgnbsk@gmail.com 2. Dr. JoeAbah - drjoeabah@gmail.com 3. Edward Asu - edward.asu@gmail.com

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
